what: CI Method Types and When to Use Them
title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Default medci() Uses Meeker & Escobar (1994) algorithm exact distribution theory accurate small samples; computationally intensive Assumes joint normality coefficient estimates Use : Accuracy matters speed Default ci() Generates samples multivariate normal, computes empirical quantiles Flexible works complex functions (via ci() formula interface) Accuracy increases n.mc (default: 1e5 medci(), 1e6 ci()) Use : Need flexibility complex mediation models multiple paths Uses delta method approximation Fast often underestimates CI width Assumes normality; questionable small samples Use : Quick approximation needed; recommended inference Returns results applicable methods Useful comparing method robustness plot=TRUE, superimposes distributions different methods

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: medci() ci() support visualization: - plot=TRUE: Displays density plot sampling distribution - plotCI=TRUE: Overlays confidence interval error bars (requires plot=TRUE) - type="", superimposes distributions different methods

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: mbco() function tests H‚ÇÄ: indirect effect = 0 via constrained optimization bootstrap refinement: Types: - ‚Äúasymp‚Äù (default): Asymptotic MBCO chi-squared test - ‚Äúparametric‚Äù: Parametric bootstrap - resamples asymptotic normal distribution MLEs (efficient, relies model specification) - ‚Äúsemi‚Äù: Semiparametric bootstrap - resamples data re-estimates models (robust misspecification, computationally intensive) OpenMx Optimization: - Default optimizer: ‚ÄúSLSQP‚Äù - Falls back SLSQP NPSOL unavailable - Precision: 1e-9 default functional precision - Arguments checkHess checkSE default ‚Äú‚Äù speed Usage pattern:
code: # Define full and null models in OpenMx full_model <- mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent=TRUE) null_model <- mxTryHard(null_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent=TRUE) mbco(h0=null_model, h1=full_model, type="asymp")

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Ignoring œÅ ‚â† 0: Can lead overly narrow CIs Small samples asymptotic method: Normal approximation breaks Effects near zero: CIs may highly asymmetric; interpret cautiously Assuming statistical significance implies causal mediation: Always consider design confounding

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: MC method medci() ci() follows pattern: Generate samples bivariate/multivariate normal distribution using MASS::mvrnorm() Compute products (arbitrary function via formula ci()) Extract empirical quantiles Œ±/2 1-Œ±/2 Report MC error: SE estimate = SD(products) / sqrt(n.mc) Memory considerations: - Default n.mc=1e5 medci() (two-variable case) - Default n.mc=1e6 ci() (general case) - large covariance matrices: length(mu) * n.mc must < .Machine$integer.max - exceeded, n.mc automatically reduced 1e6 warning Reproducibility: - Set seed calling reproducible results - MC error reported assess convergence

title: Getting Started with RMediation
text: RMediation package provides rigorous statistical methods mediation analysis observational experimental designs. addresses known limitations normal-theory confidence intervals (e.g., Sobel test) implementing advanced methods account non-normal distribution indirect effect.

title: Getting Started with RMediation
text: compute confidence interval single mediator using summary statistics:
code:
# Example: Single mediator with known coefficients and standard errors result <- medci(     mu.x = 0.5, # Effect of X on M     mu.y = 0.6, # Effect of M on Y (controlling for X)     se.x = 0.08, # Standard error of a path     se.y = 0.04, # Standard error of b path     rho = 0, # Correlation between a and b (often 0 for experimental X)     type = "dop" # Distribution of the product method )  # Display the structure of the result str(result) #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521  # Or access specific components cat("Confidence Interval:", result$`95% CI`, "
") #> Confidence Interval: 0.2010806 0.4053619 cat("Estimate:", result$Estimate, "
") #> Estimate: 0.3 cat("Standard Error:", result$SE, "
") #> Standard Error: 0.05209837

title: Getting Started with RMediation
text: RMediation integrates seamlessly popular SEM packages:
code: library(lavaan)  # Define a simple mediation model model <- '   # Direct effect   Y ~ c*X    # Mediator   M ~ a*X   Y ~ b*M    # Indirect effect   ab := a*b   # Total effect   total := c + (a*b) ' # Simulate data set.seed(123) n <- 1000 X <- rnorm(n) M <- 0.5 * X + rnorm(n) Y <- 0.3 * M + 0.2 * X + rnorm(n) df <- data.frame(X, M, Y)  # This would be fitted with your data fit <- sem(model, data = df)  # Automatically compute CI for defined parameters ci(fit) # This would auto-detect 'ab' parameter

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: vignette compares different confidence interval methods available RMediation package. Understanding differences methods important selecting appropriate approach mediation analysis.

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: RMediation provides several methods computing confidence intervals indirect effects: Distribution Product (DOP): Exact method product two normal random variables Monte Carlo (MC): Simulation-based approach using random sampling Asymptotic Normal: Traditional approach based normal theory (e.g., Sobel test) MBCO (Model-Based Constrained Optimization): Advanced frequentist method hypothesis testing

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: Let‚Äôs compare different methods using example:
code: # Same example parameters mu.x <- 0.5  # Effect of X on M mu.y <- 0.6  # Effect of M on Y (controlling for X) se.x <- 0.08 # Standard error of a path se.y <- 0.04 # Standard error of b path rho <- 0     # Correlation between a and b  # Compare all methods results <- medci(   mu.x = mu.x, mu.y = mu.y,   se.x = se.x, se.y = se.y,   rho = rho,   type = "all",  # This gives results for all methods   plot = FALSE )  # Print results for(method_name in names(results)) {   cat("\n", method_name, ":\n")   # Display the structure of each result   str(results[[method_name]]) } #>  #>  Distribution of Product : #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521 #>  #>  Monte Carlo : #> List of 4 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.2 0.404 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521 #>  $ MC.Error: num 5.21e-07 #>  #>  Asymptotic Normal : #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.198 0.402 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: Different methods different strengths weaknesses:
code:
# Example of comparing results across different parameter values  # Define parameter values to test param_sets <- list(   list(mu.x = 0.5, mu.y = 0.6, se.x = 0.08, se.y = 0.04),   list(mu.x = 0.3, mu.y = 0.4, se.x = 0.10, se.y = 0.05),   list(mu.x = 0.1, mu.y = 0.2, se.x = 0.05, se.y = 0.03) )  for(i in seq_along(param_sets)) {   params <- param_sets[[i]]   cat("
Parameter set", i, ":
")   cat("Effect sizes: a =", params$mu.x, ", b =", params$mu.y, "
")    results_subset <- medci(     mu.x = params$mu.x, mu.y = params$mu.y,     se.x = params$se.x, se.y = params$se.y,     rho = 0,     type = "all",     plot = FALSE   )    # Print confidence intervals from each method   for(method_name in names(results_subset)) {     ci_values <- results_subset[[method_name]][[1]]  # Extract CI values     cat(sprintf("%-25s: [%.3f, %.3f]
", method_name, ci_values[1], ci_values[2]))   } } #>  #> Parameter set 1 : #> Effect sizes: a = 0.5 , b = 0.6  #> Distribution of Product  : [0.201, 0.405] #> Monte Carlo              : [0.201, 0.405] #> Asymptotic Normal        : [0.198, 0.402] #>  #> Parameter set 2 : #> Effect sizes: a = 0.3 , b = 0.4  #> Distribution of Product  : [0.040, 0.209] #> Monte Carlo              : [0.040, 0.209] #> Asymptotic Normal        : [0.036, 0.204] #>  #> Parameter set 3 : #> Effect sizes: a = 0.1 , b = 0.2  #> Distribution of Product  : [0.000, 0.042] #> Monte Carlo              : [0.001, 0.042] #> Asymptotic Normal        : [-0.001, 0.041]

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: Best : Small samples normality assumptions may hold Advantages: Exact method product two normals, maintains Type error rates Disadvantages: Computationally intensive complex models
code: # Example using DOP method result_dop <- medci(   mu.x = 0.5, mu.y = 0.6,   se.x = 0.08, se.y = 0.04,   rho = 0,   type = "dop" )  cat("DOP Method Results:\n") #> DOP Method Results: str(result_dop) #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: Best : Complex models multiple mediators Advantages: Flexible, works complex functions parameters Disadvantages: Requires large sample sizes stability
code: # Example using MC method result_mc <- medci(   mu.x = 0.5, mu.y = 0.6,   se.x = 0.08, se.y = 0.04,   rho = 0,   type = "mc",   n.mc = 1e5  # Specify Monte Carlo sample size )  cat("Monte Carlo Method Results:\n") #> Monte Carlo Method Results: str(result_mc) #> List of 4 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0519 #>  $ MC.Error: num 5.19e-07

text: Best : Large samples well-behaved distributions Advantages: Computationally fast Disadvantages: Can poor Type error control small samples

# Create a ProductNormal object (represents distribution of product) pn <- ProductNormal(   mu = c(0.5, 0.6),  # Means of the two variables   Sigma = matrix(c(0.0064, 0, 0, 0.0016), 2, 2)  # Covariance matrix (se.x^2, 0, 0, se.y^2) )  # Compute cumulative distribution function cat("CDF at 0.1:", cdf(pn, q = 0.1), "
") cat("CDF at 0.3:", cdf(pn, q = 0.3), "
")  # Compute quantiles cat("2.5% quantile:", quantile(pn, p = 0.025), "
") cat("97.5% quantile:", quantile(pn, p = 0.975), "
")  # Compute confidence interval ci_result <- ci(pn, level = 0.95) cat("95% Confidence Interval:", ci_result, "
")  # Print and summary methods show(pn)  # Use show instead of print summary(pn)  # This should work as it's a different S7 method

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: Based simulation research statistical theory, practical recommendations: simple mediation models two paths: Use DOP method provides accurate confidence intervals. complex models: Use Monte Carlo methods flexible extend higher-order products. hypothesis testing: Consider using MBCO procedure provides better Type error control. publication: possible, report results multiple methods show robustness.

what: Internal: Compute CI using Asymptotic method (Delta method) ‚Äî .compute_ci_asymp
title: Internal: Compute CI using Asymptotic method (Delta method) ‚Äî .compute_ci_asymp
text: Computes asymptotic confidence intervals using normal approximation (Sobel test). standard error computed using Craig's (1936) formula: $$SE = \sqrt{\sigma_y^2\mu_x^2 + \sigma_x^2\mu_y^2 + 2\mu_x\mu_y\rho\sigma_x\sigma_y + \sigma_x^2\sigma_y^2 + \sigma_x^2\sigma_y^2\rho^2}$$ CI \(Estimate \pm z_{1-\alpha/2} \times SE\), \(z_{1-\alpha/2}\) standard normal quantile.

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test ‚Äî mbco
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(memory_exp) memory_exp$x <- as.numeric(memory_exp$x)-1 # manually creating dummy codes endVar <- c('x', 'repetition', 'imagery', 'recall') manifests <- c('x', 'repetition', 'imagery', 'recall') full_model <- OpenMx::mxModel(  "memory_example",  type = "RAM",  manifestVars = manifests,  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = "x",    to = endVar,    arrows = 1,    free = TRUE,    values = .2,    labels = c("a1", "a2", "cp")  ),  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = 'repetition',   to = 'recall',   arrows = 1,    free = TRUE,    values = .2,    labels = 'b1'  ),  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = 'imagery',  to = 'recall',  arrows = 1,  free = TRUE,  values = .2,  labels = "b2" ), OpenMx::mxPath(  from = manifests,  arrows = 2,  free = TRUE,  values = .8 ), OpenMx::mxPath(  from = "one",  to = endVar,  arrows = 1,  free = TRUE,  values = .1 ), OpenMx::mxAlgebra(a1 * b1, name = "ind1"), OpenMx::mxAlgebra(a2 * b2, name = "ind2"), OpenMx::mxCI("ind1", type = "both"), OpenMx::mxCI("ind2", type = "both"), OpenMx::mxData(observed = memory_exp, type = "raw") ) ## Reduced  Model for indirect effect: a1*b1 null_model1 <- OpenMx::mxModel( model= full_model, name = "Null Model 1", OpenMx::mxConstraint(ind1 == 0, name = "ind1_eq0_constr") ) full_model <- OpenMx::mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent = TRUE ) null_model1 <- OpenMx::mxTryHard(null_model1, checkHess=FALSE, silent = TRUE ) mbco(null_model1,full_model) } # }

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect ‚Äî medci
text: function returns confidence interval significance level \(\alpha\) mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain confidence interval using specific method, argument type specified. default type="dop", uses code wrote R implement distribution product coefficients method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach compute confidence interval (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="asymp" produces asymptotic normal confidence interval. Note except Monte Carlo method, standard error indirect effect based analytical results Craig (1936): $$SE = \sqrt{\sigma_y^2 \mu_x^2 + \sigma_x^2 \mu_y^2 + 2\mu_x\mu_y\rho\sigma_x\sigma_y + \sigma_x^2\sigma_y^2 + \sigma_x^2\sigma_y^2\rho^2}$$ \(\sigma_x\) \(\sigma_y\) standard errors \(x\) \(y\), respectively. addition, estimate indirect effect \(\mu_x\mu_y + \sigma_{xy}\), \(\sigma_{xy}\) covariance \(x\) \(y\). argument type="" prints confidence intervals using available methods. function returns (\(1-\alpha\))% confidence interval mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain confidence interval using specific method, argument type specified. default type="dop", uses code wrote R implement distribution product coefficients method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach compute confidence interval (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="asymp" produces asymptotic normal confidence interval. Note except Monte Carlo method, standard error indirect effect based analytical results Craig (1936): $$\sqrt(se.y^2 \mu.x^2+se.x^2 \mu.y^2+2 \mu.x \mu.y \rho se.x se.y+   se.x^2 se.y^2+se.x^2 se.y^2 \rho^2) $$. addition, estimate indirect effect \(\mu.x \mu.y +\sigma.xy \); type="" prints confidence intervals using four options.

title: RMediation (development version)
text: Part mediationverse ecosystem mediation analysis Integration medfit planned future release See Ecosystem Coordination guidelines

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Complete architectural redesign: S7 now computational core, legacy functions thin wrappers. Zero breaking changes: existing code continues work exactly (100% backward compatible). Enhanced extensibility: New computational architecture makes adding CI methods features straightforward.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Introduced S7 object-oriented programming modern, type-safe class definitions. ProductNormal: Represents distribution product normal random variables. MBCOResult: Encapsulates results MBCO tests. New S7 Generics: cdf(), dist_quantile(), ci(), print(), summary(), show(). S7 classes include comprehensive display methods (print, summary, show) meaningful output.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Breaking limitation removed: Can now compute confidence intervals products 3 variables. Works Monte Carlo method (type = "mc"). Example: ProductNormal(mu = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.5), Sigma = diag(3)) three-way products. Previous versions limited 2-variable products .

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: New internal S7 functions: .compute_ci_dop(), .compute_ci_mc(), .compute_ci_asymp(), .compute_cdf_dop(), .compute_cdf_mc(), .compute_quantile_dop(), .compute_quantile_mc(). core algorithms now work ProductNormal objects natively. Legacy functions (medci(), pprodnormal(), qprodnormal()) convert parameters dispatch S7 core. Identical numerical results previous versions (validated 201 tests).

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: numeric: Legacy support direct coefficient/covariance input. lavaan: Automatic extraction CI computation indirect effects. ProductNormal: Native S7 class support. Auto-detection: Automatically identifies product parameters (e.g., ab := *b) lavaan models. Renamed first argument mu better legacy compatibility.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Migrated mbco() S7 generic method MxModel objects. Returns MBCOResult S7 objects properties: statistic, df, p_value, type. Legacy Compatibility: Implemented S3 methods ($, [[, names) backward-compatible list-style access (e.g., result$chisq, result$p). Display methods show significance indicators (, , , ns) interpretation.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Comprehensive input validation using checkmate package across functions. Type checking match.arg() categorical arguments. Improved error messages invalid inputs.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: S7 classes meaningful print(), summary(), show() methods. ProductNormal displays: distribution type, means, covariance matrix, SDs, correlations. MBCOResult displays: test type, statistics, p-values significance levels, interpretation.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Zero masking warnings: Package now loads cleanly namespace conflicts. Renamed quantile() generic dist_quantile() avoid masking stats::quantile(). S7 methods print(), summary(), show() now properly register base generics. Added S4 compatibility via S7::S4_register() formal generic support.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Removed unused dependencies (doParallel, foreach, methods). Fixed documentation warnings notes. R CMD check: Now passes 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes. Added 40 new S7 prototype tests + 19 display method tests (total: 201 tests, 100% pass rate).

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Fixed argument dispatch issues alpha level parameters. Resolved S7 generic conflicts base R functions (print, summary, quantile). Fixed recursive dispatch issues display methods. Added case-insensitive handling type parameter (accepts ‚ÄúMC‚Äù, ‚Äúmc‚Äù, ‚ÄúDOP‚Äù, ‚Äúdop‚Äù, etc.). Fixed return value structure ci() method (now returns list CI, Estimate, SE components).
